{{Infobox musical artist | name = Grady Gaines | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth_date and age|1934|5|14|mf=y}}
[[Waskom, Texas|Waskom]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] | death_date = | instrument = [[Tenor saxophone]] | genre = [[Texas blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Saxophone|Saxophonist]] | years_active = Early 1950s–present | label = [[Black Top Records|Black Top]] | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|http://www.gradygaines.com/cms_home/index.html|Official website}} | notable_instruments = }} '''Grady Gaines''' (born May 14, 1934, [[Waskom, Texas|Waskom]], [[Texas]]){{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p78484/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Grady Gaines |author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 15, 2010}} is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]], [[Texas blues]] and [[jazz blues]] [[tenor saxophone|tenor saxophonist]], who performed and recorded with [[Little Richard]] in the 1950s. He also backed other [[musician]]s such as [[Dee Clark]], [[Little Willie John]], [[Sam Cooke]], [[James Brown]], [[Jackie Wilson]], and [[Joe Tex]]. He has released three [[album]]s. ==Biography== Gaines grew up in [[Houston]] with his brother, [[Roy Gaines|Roy]], who went to play guitar on [[Bobby Bland]]'s 1955 [[hit single]], "It's My Life Baby". Gaines himself worked as a [[session musician]] at [[Peacock Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gradygaines.com/cms_home/index.html |title=HOME : Grady Gaines |publisher=Gradygaines.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} He played on [[Big Walter Price]]'s "Pack Fair and Square" and [[Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown]]'s "Dirty Work at the Crossroads," before joining Little Richard's fledgling backing band, the Upsetters, as its leader in 1955. Gaines recorded infrequently, although he did play on Richard's "Keep a Knockin'" and "Ooh! My Soul." The Upsetters carried on after Richard 'retired' in 1957. They toured with Dee Clark, Little Willie John, James Brown, Jackie Wilson, and Joe Tex. The band recorded for [[Vee-Jay Records]] in 1958 backing Clark. Gaines also led [[Sam Cooke]]'s backing band up to Cooke's death. Several recording sessions followed for Gaines and his band at various [[record label|labels]] including Vee-Jay, [[Gee Records|Gee]] and [[Fire Records|Fire]]. Once the Upsetters disbanded, Grady toured with [[Millie Jackson]] and [[Curtis Mayfield]], although he stopped playing in 1980. He re-emerged in 1985, reforming the now Texas Upsetters, playing at [[concert]]s in Houston before [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] ''Full Gain'' (1988), ''Horn of Plenty'' (1992), and ''Jump Start (2002). Gaines performed in both 1989 and 1996 at the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]]. As of January 2013, Gaines continues to perform with his Texas Upsetters for private parties and wedding receptions and for public events, such as the Big Easy Social & Pleasure Club in Houston's [[Rice Village]] neighborhood. ==Discography== *''Full Gain'' (1988) - [[Black Top Records|Black Top]] *''Horn of Plenty'' (1992) - Black Top *''Jump Start'' (2002) - Gulf Coast Entertainment{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/grady-gaines-mn0000196319/discography |title=Grady Gaines | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1934-05-14 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==See also== *[[List of Texas blues musicians]] *[[List of electric blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=63619100}} {{Persondata | NAME =Gaines, Grady | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[electric blues]], [[Texas blues]] and [[jazz blues]] [[tenor saxophone|tenor saxophonist]] | DATE OF BIRTH =May 14, 1934 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Waskom, Texas]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gaines, Grady}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American saxophonists]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Texas blues musicians]] [[Category:American session musicians]]
